title: 105_s1318
content: The "Adoption Awareness Program Act" is the short title of this legislation. It establishes the Adoption Awareness Program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish an adoption awareness program and provide grants to private entities for promoting adoption through various media channels and distributing materials. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants to private entities for promoting adoption through media channels and distributing materials. Entities must submit an application to be eligible for the grant. The distribution of brochures and educational materials must be coordinated with Title X of the Public Health Service Act. The entity cannot distribute materials until the Secretary has reviewed and approved them. The Secretary will make grants to selected recipients for promoting adoption, with a 50% Federal cost share requirement. Non-Federal contributions can be in cash or in kind. Establishment of Commission. The Adoption Awareness Commission is established with 7 members appointed by the President, Senate majority and minority leaders, and House Speaker and minority leader. The Adoption Awareness Commission, consisting of 7 members appointed for life, reviews grant applications and public service announcements, making recommendations to the Secretary. They meet at least 4 times per fiscal year. The Adoption Awareness Commission meets at least 4 times a year. Members who are not federal employees receive compensation, while those who are federal employees serve without additional pay. Members are also reimbursed for travel expenses. The Adoption Awareness Commission meets regularly and compensates non-federal employee members. Federal employees serve without extra pay and can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman can procure temporary services at specified rates. The Commission will terminate on September 30, 2002. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2002.
